awd_titl_txt: Optical MIMO and Hybrid Communication Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Objective:

The objective of this research is to develop and analyze multiple-input multiple-output optical communication systems using light-emitting diodes and a focal plane receiving array to provide reliable and secure communications under both static and mobile scenarios. The proposed approach explores novel spatio-temporal processing, effective modulations that exploit diversity and multiplexing,
and hybrid optical/radio frequency communication.

Intellectual merit:

The intellectual merit includes: (1) development of transmission techniques and receiver signal processing algorithms to provide high data rate communication using light-emitting diodes under channel impairments and varying transmitter-receiver distances, (2) modulations and adaptive mode analysis for hybrid optical/radio frequency systems, (3) investigation of indoor and outdoor channel effects on the proposed algorithms including acquisition and tracking, (4) testing and validation of key ideas on an experimental test bed, and (5) exploring design optimization using channel codes.

Broader impacts:

The broader impacts include high speed optical communication system development that can integrate well with energy saving light-emitting diode lighting technology. The proposed research can offer secure communication solutions to inter-vehicle and vehicle-to-hub communications, and communications in indoor and factory facilities. The work can also inspire new receiving device
developments with novel sensing and communication architectures offering potential benefits to society. Students will be trained in theory and in the laboratory, and efforts will be made to attract students from underrepresented groups. Plans are included to demonstrate this research to local high school students to help motivate them to pursue engineering studies.

por.por_cntn:
Optical wireless communication systems have several advantages over radio frequency (RF) systems.  They offer huge unlicensed spectrum and  reduced interference. Due to their line-of-sight (LOS) mode of operation, it is very difficult to intercept or eavesdrop optical wireless signals. Further,  they pose no serious health issues and do not interfere with RF signals.  The purpose of this project was to develop and analyze novel techniques  to make optical wireless more efficient and reliable.   Two research directions were planned for study. The first direction is to investigate the use of  camera receivers with light-emitting diode (LED) transmitters so that strict pointing requirements between the transmitter and the receiver can be relaxed. The idea involves localization of the engaged camera pixels, and then the use of those pixels to extract and process the transmitted data. The second direction was to enhance the optical link reliability by adding  an RF link of much lower power and bandwidth.

There are several major findings from the project. First, a novel mathematical model that integrates radiometry with imaging structures to analyze LED image reception by a digital camera for visible light communications has been developed. The model has been extensively validated through a test bed using different types of LEDs and digital cameras. Second,  optimal transmit symbols for spatial modulations of LED arrays have been designed. Toward this end, two algorithms and their variations are developed. Performance under channel impairments and various transmitter-receiver distances have been studied. Third, recognizing that the receiver data at the camera output must be highly compressed for high speed communication, a compressive parameter estimation algorithm is developed based on a Bayesian framework. The proposed method exploits inter-frame temporal correlations and exploits possible transmitter mobility through a parametric framework. Fourth,  a mobile multiuser communication system is proposed and investigated. The idea involves identifying the engaged pixels of the digital camera during an acquisition phase. The detected pixels are then clustered and tracked using Kalman Filters. Simultaneous communications from multiple mobile users with signifcantly compressed data have been demonstrated. Finally, the project also studied hybrid optical/radio frequency communication that has the potential to save enormous RF bandwidths. This part of the project focusses on relay networks, and investigates the performance benefits of optimal symbol mappings and the adaptations based on the signal-to-noise ratios in hybrid channels. Overall,  these findings have resulted in  several research articles. They include four published refereed journal articles and two published refereed conference papers. Additionally, one journal article is in preparation. Further, as an outreach effort, two additional conference papers have also been presented at a telemetry conference.

The broader impacts of this research include teaching and training activities.  Six graduate students were trained. These include three PhD and three MS students. Several undergraduate students too participated in this research via a senior capstone project. The trained  students include multiple persons from underrepresented groups.  In addition, some of the concepts learnt from the project are disseminated to the broader undergraduate student community through coursework and  hardware projects. This research also contributed to outreach activities.  A total of 42 middle and high school students visited this lab. Experiments were specifically designed to make the project attractive to school students. Hands-on activities for school students were developed, and the students were asked to actively participate in the project under the college preparatory program.
